Triggering Event: A retired doctor, now 65, walks past his old clinic's window each morning. Today, he sees his former partner laughing with their new young associate inside, holding a framed photo of them all, taken years ago at a conference. The bitterness rises in his throat like bile as he realizes he's been replaced, not just professionally, but also in the affections of those who were once his colleagues and friends.
Generated Assessment: What the hell is this? I've been walking past that stupid clinic every day for months now, and today I finally caught up with my old partner. And what does he have there? Some new little fucker, standing next to him with an arm around his waist. They're laughing together, and they look happy. Happy! Me? Forget it. I'm still the same guy who used to be the best doctor this town has ever seen. But no, everyone's forgotten about me. It doesn't even matter that I spent decades building this place from scratch. No one remembers that. All they care about is how much money they can make off their latest gimmicks. My own clinic, which was always more than just a business, has become nothing more than a memory—a reminder of how far we've fallen. How could they forget us? And now this? This little...this kid! He looks so fucking young, and they're smiling together. What am I supposed to feel? Joy? Ha! I don't feel anything except rage and humiliation. Why would I want to be replaced by some idiot who didn't even work here before? Did you think you could just waltz in here and steal my patients? Steal everything I worked hard for? You must think you're better than me, huh? That you deserve to take my place because you're younger and prettier? Well, let me tell you something, pal—you'll never be me. Never!

Triggering Event: He found a crumpled note in his partner's pocket, an apology for a forgotten lunch date with an old friend.
Generated Assessment: He's either going to break up with me because he didn't like it when I called him out on his lack of communication about our relationship; or he'll ignore my feelings and continue pursuing this friend who clearly has more time for her. ## Edit: To clarify, I am using "or" as opposed to "and." It is possible that both things happen at once. Also, I was trying to convey how this person might be thinking without directly saying they're doing all-or-nothing thinking. Hopefully this makes sense! If you'd like me to rephrase anything, feel free to let me know. Thank you for your kind responses! :) Edit #2: Thank you so much for everyone’s thoughtful comments. I really appreciate it. I have been reading through all of these and I can see how some people interpret it differently. This particular post was based on my own experiences and thoughts around the subject. My intention was to illustrate a specific way of thinking rather than make an absolute statement. So, thank you again for all the love and support. And if anyone would like me to expand upon this, I’d be happy to do so. :D <3 <3 <3<3<3<3<3<3<3<3<3<3<3<3<3<3<3<3<3<3<3<3<3<3<3<3<3<3<3<3<3<3

Triggering Event: He sat alone in his cramped apartment, the clock's hands inching closer to midnight. His phone buzzed with an email alert. The subject line read: "Final Draft - Humanitarian Crisis Report." He had been so caught up in the grind of daily news that he'd almost forgotten about this. As he opened it, his eyes scanned the lines he'd written weeks ago, now approved by his editor. The words seemed foreign, distant, as if they belonged to someone else. He remembered the faces of those he'd interviewed, their desperate stories. A pang of remorse hit him like a punch in the gut. How could he have let this slip from his mind? His deadline-driven existence suddenly felt hollow. He picked up his pen, determined to rewrite it all, to make sure their voices were truly heard.
Generated Assessment: He stared at the screen, dumbfounded. How did this happen? He was supposed to be working on a story, not staring blankly into space. His boss would kill him for this. He couldn't just sit here, wasting time, when there was work to be done. How could he have let himself fall asleep? This wasn't how he usually spent his free time. What kind of pathetic excuse is this? He's always busy, always stressed, never enough time for anything. And yet...he'd rather sleep than stare at screens all day. It's stupid, but it feels good to shut off. Maybe I'm just getting lazy, huh? Maybe it's because I'm tired, maybe it's because I don't want to think about it anymore. But damn, I really need to get back to work. He sighed and rubbed his eyes, feeling more awake. Yet, the guilt lingered, like a shadow over his shoulders. He forced himself to focus on the task at hand, but deep down, he knew he couldn't shake this feeling anytime soon. He tried to push it aside, telling himself he needed to stop being such a whiner. But the truth was, he couldn't help feeling guilty – guilty about letting himself fall asleep, guilty about not being able to concentrate fully, and most of all, guilty about the stress eating up every waking moment of his life. His head spun as he tried to catch up. He pushed aside the thoughts

Triggering Event: At 10 AM, a familiar email from the local gallery pops up in her inbox. She hesitates before clicking it open; she knows they've had her paintings for weeks now. The words stare back at her starkly: "We regret to inform you..."
Generated Assessment: "Ugh, another fucking rejection? I know how that feels. Always getting rejected by galleries, never being accepted. It's always the same with me. Whole artists like me are destined to be ignored. I'm going through this entire year and it just keeps happening. Entirely useless effort, my art is never appreciated anyway. Why bother continuing when everyone else has already given up on me?"

Triggering Event: She noticed his laptop screen lit up with her friend's profile picture as he worked from home, late into the night again.
Generated Assessment: "Are you kidding me? You're still working from home at 11 pm again?! I've told you multiple times that this is not okay. You need to be more responsible and set boundaries for yourself. This isn't how you treat your family. It's just so infuriating." ---

Triggering Event: He noticed it tucked behind his keyboard at work, yellowed with age: their old wedding photo. A stark reminder of what once was, now tarnished by silence and separation. He felt a pang of shame, recalling the echoes of arguments that still rang in his ears after all these years.

He just wants to move forward and get back to living his life. I think he's doing great considering everything. Maybe you're just bitter because she left you. You know, maybe if she didn't leave, things would be different today. But now we have to deal with the reality of our situation. You can't change the past, but you can control how you react to it. It's time to let go and focus on the present. Look, I understand that it hurts, but blaming her isn't going to help anything. She made a choice, and now you have to accept it. Let's keep moving forward instead of dwelling on the past. It’s just an old picture. It doesn’t define the entire relationship. Instead of focusing on the past, why don’t you try to find ways to improve the present? Life is too short to dwell on something like that. That picture may remind him of the past, but it shouldn’t dictate his future. Have you tried reaching out to him? Maybe talking things through could bring some closure. Just saying. Let's not forget that relationships involve two people, not just one. If she left, there must have been reasons. Are you taking full responsibility for those reasons? Triggering Event: An elderly woman, her hands trembling with anger, watched as a young cashier at the store she'd worked in for decades snapped at a customer over a minor discrepancy in prices. She felt a surge of resentment at being spoken to like that once herself, after years of loyalty and service. Her face flushed red, she slammed her fist on the counter, "I've had enough of this nonsense!"
Generated Assessment: You know what really gets my goat? You can't trust anyone anymore! I saw an old lady lose it today because some kid was rude to her. He was just trying to be helpful, but she snapped at him, saying she's had enough. It's so typical of people my age. They're always complaining about something, never satisfied. And those who are happy all the time? Forget about them, they must be faking it. I'm sick of seeing everyone act this way. Everyone is a jerk these days, and I'm tired of it. The world has gone mad.

Triggering Event: In the chaotic heart of the ER, she's rushed to triage a young man with severe burns. Suddenly, his monitor starts beeping erratically. Her heart pounds as she realizes it's mirroring her own racing pulse. She freezes, trapped in a familiar flashback—her ex-husband's crash scene, the blaring sirens, the helplessness. Panic surges, but she must act.
Generated Assessment: **It was like I knew what was coming before it even started.** The patient’s vitals were off, and my mind instantly went into overdrive. **What if this is a sign of an undiagnosed condition? What if he needs immediate surgery?** But then, my gaze fell upon the monitors, and my thoughts stopped abruptly. It was just another patient, another emergency. Yet, I couldn’t shake off the feeling that I’d seen it all before. **What if I missed something? What if I didn't react fast enough last time?** My heart began to race, just like during those flashbacks. I felt a wave of panic wash over me, and my hands trembled. **What if I’m too late again? What if I can't save him?** My mind was racing with worst-case scenarios. **What if this is another accident? What if he needs more than just treatment?** The thought sent a chill down my spine, and I had to remind myself to focus on the present moment. But still, my mind kept wondering about the what-ifs. **What if I don’t have the right equipment? What if I need additional training?** The list of potential problems went on, and I felt my anxiety spike. I took a deep breath and tried to clear my head, but the thoughts lingered. **What if I make things worse? What if I'm not good enough?** The fear of failing crept

Triggering Event: In the sterile silence of his lab, he noticed a smudge on his pristine petri dish. His heart quickened as he realized it wasn't dirt; it was an unfamiliar bacteria strain. He felt his anxiety spike, imagining the potential contamination, the ruined experiments, the ridicule from his peers if this was a mistake.
Generated Assessment: "Are you kidding me? The incompetence is staggering! I could've sworn they were being careful—now look at that mess! Do you know how many times I've warned them about this? And yet, still nothing changes. It's like they're trying to sabotage everything. If only they'd follow instructions half the time...if only they didn't make such a mess..."

Triggering Event: A man, his hands trembling slightly from years of typing code and holding a photo of his late wife, slammed his fist against the desk when he saw an email from her old address pop up in his inbox, still addressed to "Dear Honey," after all these years.
Generated Assessment: A man's actions are always driven by anger; he never shows love for his wife, even though he has been grieving for decades. His behavior is entirely negative, as evidenced by his tendency to slam his fists in frustration when he receives emails that remind him of her. This pattern demonstrates that he will always react with anger whenever something triggers memories of his deceased partner, whether it be an email, a phone call, or simply a random thought. He can't handle anything remotely related to her, so he must act out in anger every time. When faced with reminders of her life, such as her old email account, he becomes enraged, revealing his true nature as someone who hates everything connected to her. Even though he may have loved her once, now he cannot bear the thought of her, and this constant anger indicates that he will always reject anything associated with her. It’s clear that he doesn’t care about her at all; he’s just angry because she died, and this anger will last forever. His reaction to the email is proof that he will never show affection again, and he’s doomed to live a life filled with hatred towards anything that reminds him of her.
